metadata.title: Shak'er Chayka | শাকের ছ্যাকা | Rural Recipes
metadata.description:
Shak'er Chayka by Shipra Roy | রুরাল রেসিপির একুশ তম পর্ব, জলপাইগুড়ির জল্পেশের বাসিন্দা শিপ্রা রায়ের হাতের রান্না :  শাকের ছ্যাকা

Rural local recipes are integral part of Intangible Cultural Heritage and needs to be preserved and promoted. We at banglanatak dot com have been working for the past 22+ years to safeguard and promote local cultural heritages in rural spaces across India.  We are now launching a new initiative of documenting rural recipes and bringing them closer to the food lovers of the world.  We request all to subscribe to our new channel Rural Recipes and stay tuned there to know, learn and try out local delicacies.

Presenter: Jamil Akhtar
ingredients_detected: Khar (Alkaline water made from burnt Atiya banana stem ash)

transcription_bengali: [00:00:12] হ্যালো, রুরাল রেসিপি ইউটিউব চ্যানেলে স্বাগতম।
[00:00:17] এখন আমরা উত্তরবঙ্গে, আর দাঁড়িয়ে আছি ভারত-বাংলাদেশ সীমান্তের কাছে।
[00:00:22] আসলে এখান থেকে একটু দূরে কাঁটাতার দেখা যাচ্ছে।
[00:00:30] আরেকটা মজার ব্যাপার হলো, এখানে দাঁড়ালে এয়ারটেল/ভোডাফোন/জিও নয়—
[00:00:43] কিন্তু আজ আমরা যাচ্ছি জলপাইগুড়ি জেলার ছোট শহর—জল্পেশে।
[00:00:54] এই মুহূর্তে আমি দাঁড়িয়ে আছি বিখ্যাত জল্পেশ মন্দিরের সামনে।
[00:00:57] এই মন্দির এই এলাকার অন্যতম জনপ্রিয় মন্দির।
[00:01:02] তবে আজকের এপিসোড শুট করতে আমরা ভেতরে যাব।
[00:01:11] কেমন আছো, সিমরতি? (নাম উচ্চারণ/ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে অস্পষ্ট—আসলে শিপ্রা হতে পারে)
[00:01:15] স্টেশনে দেখা হওয়ায় খুব ভালো লাগল।
[00:01:32] দর্শকরা আপনার বাড়ি থেকে কী দেখবেন?
[00:01:45] আমি শুনেছি আরেকটা পদ আছে ‘ছ্যাকা’ আর ‘পেলকা’।
[00:02:34] ‘আতিয়া’ কলাগাছের কাণ্ড দিয়ে ক্ষার বানানো হয়।
[00:02:39] কাণ্ড তুলে ছোট ছোট করে কেটে নিই।
[00:03:05] (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে ‘তেল-হলুদ’ বলা হলেও পরে বলা হচ্ছে তেল/হলুদ লাগে না—এখানে অসঙ্গতি আছে)
[00:03:09] একটা রেসিপি যেটাতে তেল, পেঁয়াজ, হলুদ, আর লঙ্কা গুঁড়ো লাগে না।
[00:03:21] গ্রামে এসে নুন দিয়ে রান্নার অভিজ্ঞতা হচ্ছে।
[00:03:48] তারপর কাঁচা লঙ্কা কেটে নিতে হবে।
[00:04:13] তাহলে বেশি কাঁচা লঙ্কা আর চটকানো রসুন দিচ্ছেন।
[00:04:16] এবার জল ফুটতে হবে, তাই তো?
[00:04:43] শিপ্রা, আপনি কি এই মাটির হাঁড়িতেই রান্না করেন?
[00:05:08] না, আমরা গ্যাস ব্যবহার করি না—
[00:05:10] (ট্রান্সক্রিপ্টে ‘ক্লে টেন্ডারাইজার’ বলা—সম্ভবত ক্ষার/মাটির হাঁড়ির প্রভাব বোঝাচ্ছে)
[00:05:30] আর ক্ষার/মাটির হাঁড়ি—এই দিয়েই হয়ে যাবে।
[00:05:59] দিদি, আপনি অনেকদিন ধরে রান্না করছেন—
[00:06:15] আর হলুদ শাক (অর্থাৎ আলাদা পাতার ধরন),
[00:06:16] আর পেলকা বানানো হয় ‘লাপা’ দিয়ে (অস্পষ্ট/স্থানীয় উপকরণ)।
[00:07:58] আর এর সঙ্গে মাংস খাওয়া যাবে না,
[00:08:17] আজ আমরা যে পদটা রান্না করলাম,
[00:08:44] এর সঙ্গে বেশি ভাত খাওয়া যায়।
transcription_english: [00:00:12] Hello, welcome to the Rural Recipe YouTube channel.
[00:00:17] We are now in North Bengal, standing near the India–Bangladesh border.
[00:00:22] In fact, you can see the border fencing a little distance from here.
[00:00:27] Across it is East Bengal—today’s Bangladesh.
[00:00:30] Another interesting thing is: if you stand here, you won’t get Airtel/Vodafone/Jio—
[00:00:37] you’ll be greeted by a Bangladeshi operator, Grameenphone.
[00:00:41] We are that close to the Bangladesh border.
[00:00:43] But today we are going to Jalpesh, a small town in Jalpaiguri district.
[00:00:51] So we have arrived in Jalpesh.
[00:00:54] Right now I am standing in front of the famous Jalpesh temple.
[00:00:57] This temple is one of the most popular temples in this region.
[00:01:02] But for today’s episode, we will go inside to shoot.
[00:01:11] How are you? (name unclear in transcript; likely Shipra)
[00:01:15] I’m glad to see you at the station.
[00:01:20] This village is very beautiful.
[00:01:22] There’s a bamboo grove on one side and a tea garden on the other.
[00:01:27] There are many dogs here.
[00:01:28] In this episode, what will you do?
[00:01:32] What will viewers see from your house?
[00:01:34] We have an old dish that we eat—
[00:01:38] it is called Chheka (Chayka).
[00:01:45] I’ve heard there are two dishes: Chheka and Pelka—both Rajbanshi dishes.
[00:01:50] Yes, both are Rajbanshi dishes.
[00:01:52] Chheka is made with leafy vegetables.
[00:01:55] One leafy item is called “kacha”.
[00:01:57] This is sajna pata (drumstick leaves).
[00:01:59] This is kochu pata (taro leaves).
[00:02:01] We add these to chheka—
[00:02:03] not more than one or two.
[00:02:05] We cut the raw leaves with a knife,
[00:02:10] then wash them with clean water.
[00:02:13] After washing, we start cooking.
[00:02:17] All the leaves are ready—cut and kept.
[00:02:22] What are the remaining ingredients?
[00:02:25] One more thing is left—khar.
[00:02:30] We add khar to it.
[00:02:32] What is khar made from?
[00:02:34] Khar is made from the ash of an “Atiya” banana stem.
[00:02:39] We collect the stem, cut it into small pieces,
[00:02:43] dry it in the sun,
[00:02:45] then burn it on fire.
[00:02:48] We keep it stored,
[00:02:50] and use it when we cook chheka.
[00:02:53] Then we keep it (even in the fridge) at home and use it later.
[00:02:59] What else is here?
[00:03:00] Garlic is used for chheka,
[00:03:02] along with green chili and salt.
[00:03:05] (Transcript has some inconsistency about oil/turmeric, but the key point said next is: no oil/onion/turmeric/chili powder.)
[00:03:09] Very interesting—a recipe that doesn’t require oil, onion, turmeric, or chili powder.
[00:03:16] We are heating salt.
[00:03:28] Will there be water in the pot?
[00:03:31] Yes, there will be water.
[00:03:35] Then we crush the garlic.
[00:03:38] Does the water have to be hot?
[00:03:40] It can be hot or cold.
[00:03:48] Then we cut green chilies—two—just for taste.
[00:03:58] Some people eat a lot of chili; we need only a little,
[00:04:02] because some leaves can be bitter otherwise.
[00:04:09] If we add more garlic it will be tastier.
[00:04:16] Then the water has to boil, right?
[00:04:18] Yes—it has to boil, and we add only as much salt as needed,
[00:04:22] otherwise it will be too salty to eat.
[00:04:28] When it boils, then I will add the leaves.
[00:04:43] Do you cook in this clay pot?
[00:04:45] Yes, mostly. I don’t use gas.
[00:04:51] The water is boiling—now I’m adding the leaves.
[00:04:59] It won’t take much time—once we add leaves, it’s almost ready.
[00:05:08] We don’t use gas; we use clay pots (traditional cooking).
[00:05:20] Now stir it—let it cook properly.
[00:05:28] With just a few leaves and khar/clay-pot cooking, it becomes ready.
[00:05:32] Is it popular here?
[00:05:34] Very popular and also very useful/healthy.
[00:05:37] For high blood pressure, people eat it sometimes—
[00:05:43] it helps keep blood pressure under control.
[00:05:49] It cleans the stomach.
[00:05:53] Honestly, it’s good because it has very little oil and spices, so it’s easy on the stomach.
[00:05:59] There is another dish called Pelka—what is it made of, and how is it different?
[00:06:10] Pelka is made with bay leaves and different kinds of leafy greens (some local items mentioned, unclear: “lapa”).
[00:06:22] With a little salt it becomes aromatic and very tasty.
[00:06:27] So it’s good for winter?
[00:06:29] Yes, good for winter.
[00:06:33] Chheka and Pelka are popular dishes.
[00:06:38] Do we need to cover it?
[00:06:41] No, and the flame is kept low.
[00:06:51] It’s very easy and quick.
[00:06:55] It’s cooked—now I’ll mix it; it will become soft and tasty.
[00:07:23] You reduced the flame—yes.
[00:07:28] It has a soupy consistency; then it will be soft.
[00:07:38] Cover it (brief instruction).
[00:07:47] Shipra, chheka is ready.
[00:07:49] Yes, it’s ready.
[00:07:50] Can I taste it?
[00:07:52] Of course.
[00:07:53] It needs rice—yes—
[00:07:57] and then jaggery.
[00:07:58] And with it you shouldn’t eat meat, eggs, or lemon (as per custom).
[00:08:17] So the dish we cooked today is chheka.
[00:08:37] It’s very simple but very tasty—
[00:08:44] you can eat more rice with it.
[00:08:48] With a few ingredients, you can make such a tasty dish—amazing.
[00:08:56] You have another identity—you are an artist; you sing. Is it from your family?
[00:09:11] Yes, from my family, since childhood.
[00:09:22] Shipra, the dress you’re wearing—what is it?
[00:09:26] It’s not a sari—it’s called a “patani”.
[00:09:34] It’s comfortable to wear, not as big as a sari, and it’s our traditional dress.
[00:09:43] Do you perform wearing it?
[00:09:47] I request you to sing a song—even one.
[00:10:09] So, you must have liked today’s episode.
[00:10:13] If you liked it, subscribe to our channel and like it.
[00:10:20] Tell us in the comments how you liked today’s episode.
[00:10:26] We will come back with a new recipe from another village.
[00:10:35] Thank you.
